newsitem.title: LEBANON: Banks regain momentum on Beirut Stock Exchange.
newsitem.headline: Banks regain momentum on Beirut Stock Exchange.

text.p: Bank shares regained momentum on the Beirut Stock Exchange in the week ending Friday, driven by Banque Audi's midweek surge to a new high.

Two banks rose and the third listed bank stock was steady, but a fall by Solidere, which accounts for $2 billion of total market capitalisation of $2.4 billion, held back overall market performance despite an increase in turnover.
The LIBX bank index rose 3.22 percent to 158.73 but the LISPI general index fell 1.22 percent to 88.33 and the BLOM general index fell 0.93 percent to 923.49.
Market turnover rose to 917,885 shares for a value of $12,590,502 from 710,563 shares and $6,376,190 last week.
Brokers were bullish after bank shares emerged from two weeks of sideways trading.
"The market was searching for direction and it found one, an upward trend. I expect very active trade next week," a broker who asked not to be identified told Reuters.
Banque Audi jumped to an all-time high of $25.125 in mid-week but fell back to $24.875 on Friday, seven percent above last week's closing of $23.25.
"Audi definitely contributed a lot. There was also a lot of over-the-counter activity on Byblos Bank shares which in turn affects trade in bank stocks on the exchange," the broker said.

Byblos A and B shares were bought at $7.5 and $7.75 on Friday from $6.88 and $7.13 respectively a week earlier. The long-awaited listing of the stock is expected in September, according to bank officials.
The broker said the recent rise of Audi's Global Depository Receipts to $27 on the Luxembourg Stock Exchange was likely to reflect on Beirut prices of the underlying share next week.
Of the other listed banks, Banque Libanaise pour le Commerce rose to $18.5 from $18 and Bank of Beirut was unchanged at $3.9375.
Solidere A fell to $10.25 from $10.5 while Solidere B shares remained unchanged at $10.75.
"The shares will eventually go up. The company GDRs are trading at $16 in London," the broker said.
Ciments Libanais was active throughout the week at an unchanged price of $1.28125. On Monday, a block of 200,000 shares traded off the floor at $1.3125.
"Ciments Libanais is still in consolidation. It is going to go up," the broker said.
Eternit, which traded 1,000 shares during the week, fell to $1.875 from $2. Ciments Blancs fell to $4.125 from $4.75 on May 29 when they were last traded.
There was no trade in the fourth listed industrial firm Uniceramic.
